column12: I’ll add that many animals are killed and habitats destroyed to produce arable crops. Rabbits are regularly shot and killed to protect crops. If a farmer has a particularly bad rabbit problem i.e. a large
column14: they may use a gas bomb like the Rodenator to destroy the warren and kill or relocate the rabbits. Also works well to kill rats and moles. Harvesting crops kills or destroys the homes of many small animals like mice. Even organic farming uses pesticides to kill insects. Poison is used to protect stored food such as grains from rats and mice.Pest control is essential for food production. Without it farmers worldwide simply would not be able to meet the demand for food. It is literally impossible to live cruelty free in modern western society. Animals have been used as resources
column16: and harmed indirectly by humans for millenia. Humans have exploited each other probably since before we were recognisable as humans. There’s also the environmental footprint of producing and importing food. All we can do is reduce harm. Being vegan does not mean you are living a cruelty free life.  I’m surprised nobody’s brought up palm oil yet. Thousands of orangutans a year are displaced or outright killed to make room for commercial palm oil farming. Palm oil is one of the most commonly used vegan cooking fats.  All you fine vegan folk out there
column20: imperfect process to work to improve things. Don’t feel that the steps your taking are futile because they’re imperfect
column22: don’t think that the steps you’re taking are flawless and blemish-free either. They all have their own sets of problems. As heterotrophic organisms
column23: we’ll always be consuming energy that other living things have processed first
column24: and any path to making that impact less significant to other things is great

column1: kinkywaifu 143636505413 "2016-04-30 16:12:28 GMT" https://kinkywaifu.tumblr.com/post/143636505413/may-is-masturbation-month "masturbatorsanctum: The celebration of May as United States’ National Masturbation Month began in 1995 in San Francisco as a response to the forced resignation of then U.S. Surgeon General Joycelyn Elders.After a speech at the United Nations World AIDS Day in 1994
column2: an audience member asked Elders about masturbation’s potential for discouraging early sexual activity. She answered
column3: “I think it is something that is part of human sexuality and a part of something that perhaps should be taught.” This answer caused a puritanical uproar and as a result was the end of Elders’ career as United States’ first black Surgeon General. All that bashing against Elders sparked the idea of a National Masturbation Month.Why do we need an entire month to educate people on something they are supposedly already enjoying ? To put an end to the hypocrisy. Masturbation is a healthy habit on many levels (it has been shown many times)
column4: but the social stigma associated to masturbation spoils most of the psychological benefits of masturbation by encouraging guilt and a feeling of inappropriateness.“We could talk about the physical
column5: psychological and emotional benefits to this
column7: it feels good and doesn’t hurt anyone. It’s so incredibly common and yet it’s vilified.” (Charlie Glickman)This is why we need a time in the year to educate people on masturbation. We need this time to put an end to the public demonizing that ends up uselessly hurting and crippling many lives.Freeing yourself of the unwarranted stigmatization of masturbation won’t cause you to masturbate more (unless you were trying to restrict yourself because of this)
column8: it will simply allow you to masturbate serenely. Because whatever the many health reasons we can evoke to justify masturbation
column9: we all masturbate because it feels good. Not feeling guilty will make your masturbation even better." False link

column1: kinkywaifu 128860351723 "2015-09-11 18:46:49 GMT" https://kinkywaifu.tumblr.com/post/128860351723/youtube-star-nicole-arbour-fired-after-fat-shaming "dynastylnoire: consttantine:  Karma’s a bitch. Days after posting a controversial video on YouTube titled “Dear Fat People""—where she jokes about obesity and even compares some overweight people to slow-moving zombies—Nicole Arbour is out of the job. It turns out that Pat Mills has decided to drop the YouTube star from an upcoming movie and told Zap2it why he never wants to see Arbour again. ”[I’m making] a dance movie
column2: so obviously we needed a choreographer. We met with a woman who not only did traditional dance choreography
column3: but was a cheerleader as well. She was fun and nice and had a lot of energy
column4: “ Mills told the site. “She seemed like a perfect fit for the project. I shared the script with her. She said she dug it and was excited to come on board…and then a crazy thing happened on Saturday—I saw something on the Internet that made me never want to see her again.” Mills continued to explains how Arbour’s fat-shaming comments completely contradict the message behind Don’t Talk to Irene
column6: “It’s a body-positive teen dance movie set in a retirement home. It’s about a 16-year-old girl who dreams of being a cheerleader
column7: but she is constantly being bullied for being fat.” In the end
column9: the main character “learns that she doesn’t have to change anything about herself to be awesome because she already is.” Mills also wanted to note that Arbour’s viral bullying hit a nerve for another reason. “I’m gay
column10: I was bullied a lot as a kid. I’m no stranger to ridicule and loneliness. [Her video] is an unfunny and cruel fat-shaming video that guises itself about being about ‘health.’ It’s fat phobic and awful…I was so upset I was shaking.”  Wommmmmmmp. " False link
